subject: Science
title: Voltage: The Electrical Pressure
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Voltage: The Electrical Pressure.

hook.text: Voltage is the 'pressure' that pushes electrons through a wire â€” like water pressure in a hose.

buildup.text: A battery creates a voltage difference between its two terminals using chemical reactions.

discovery.text: Higher voltage means more force pushing electrons. A car battery is 12V; a wall outlet is 120-240V.

twist.text: A static shock can be 25,000 volts â€” but the current is tiny, so it's harmless.

climax.text: It's current that kills, not voltage. High voltage with low current is safe; low voltage with high current is deadly.

punchline.text: Voltage pushes. Current flows. It's the combination that matters â€” not voltage alone.

quiz.question: Why isn't a 25,000-volt static shock deadly?
